conclusion: Displacement is the area under the velocity-time graph.
If the velocity is positive, the object is moving forward; if negative, moving backward.
The total displacement is the net area under the curve.
Both curves start at the origin (0,0) and end at the same point on the x-axis (t1).
The area under each curve represents the displacement of the respective object.
At any given time t within the interval [0, t1], compare the area under the curve for object A with object B.
Since both objects start and end at the same points, the total displacements of both objects will be equal at t1.
The rate of change of displacement is given by the velocity.
Object A has a higher initial velocity and accelerates more steeply initially than object B.
Object B has a lower initial velocity but accelerates more gradually and reaches a higher peak velocity before decelerating.
Initially, object A's area under the curve is larger than object B's.
As time progresses, the areas under the curves will continue to increase.
The areas under the curves will eventually converge to the same value at t1.
The difference in displacement between the two objects is not necessarily continuously increasing.
There will be a moment when the difference in displacement stops increasing and starts decreasing.
Final answer: No, the difference in displacement is not necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
